about.title: About Calculations
about.prayerTimesBody: Prayer times are calculated using solar geometry. Fajr and Isha depend on the sun's angle below the horizon, which varies by convention. Different organizations use slightly different angles, resulting in a few minutes' difference between methods.
about.asrBody: The Shafi'i method begins Asr when an object's shadow equals its height plus its noon shadow (shadow factor 1). The Hanafi method begins when the shadow equals twice the object's height plus its noon shadow (shadow factor 2), resulting in a later Asr time.
about.crescentBody: The Islamic month begins at the sighting of the new crescent moon. Different authorities apply different visibility criteria: Umm al-Qura uses calculations for Mecca, ISNA uses astronomical calculations for North America, MABIMS uses altitude/elongation thresholds for Southeast Asia, and others use their own regional standards.
about.hijriBody: The Hijri calendar is a purely lunar calendar of 12 months. Astronomical calculations predict when the crescent should be visible, but actual sighting may differ by 1-2 days due to weather and local conditions. The tabular method uses a fixed arithmetic cycle as a fallback.
about.disclaimer: This app provides astronomical calculations only. For religious rulings, consult your local authority.
